Award.AwardTitle: Riemann-Hilbert Problems, Integrable Systems and Random Matrix Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI plans to work on a variety of problems, particularly asymptotic problems, in the general area of integrable systems. Two key tools will play a prominent role in the PI's work: Riemann-Hilbert Problems (RHP) and the non-linear, non-commutative steepest descent method, on the one hand, and Random Matrix Theory (RMT) on the other. RHPs can be viewed as the natural, non-commutative generalization of the scalar integral representations of the classical special functions, and just as the classical steepest descent method allows one to evaluate the asymptotic behavior of the classical functions, so too the non-linear, non-commutative steepest descent method allows one to evaluate the asymptotic behavior of modern integrable systems such as the KdV equation and the Painleve equations, amongst many others. RMT, and in particular, the eigenvalues of random matrices, provide an extremely versatile tool to describe the behavior of a wide variety of stochastic phenomena when the underlying variables are no longer independent. Amongst the problems that the PI will address with these tools are: the asymptotic behavior of the modes of a laser as the Fresnel number goes to infinity; the behavior of random n-band matrices of size N as n,N go to infinity; universality for general orthogonal and symplectic matrix ensembles; the perturbation theory of the focusing Non-Linear Schroedinger Equation on the line.


It is an extraordinary fact that the eigenvalues of random matrices provide a quantitative model for a wide variety of statistical phenomena from physics, pure and applied mathematics, and engineering. Applications of RMT range from the analysis of resonances in nuclear scattering theory, to the analysis of the zeroes of the Riemann zeta function on the critical line, in analytic number theory.Quite spectacularly, and surprisingly, even the arrival times between buses in the Mexican city of Cuernavaca, have been shown to obey random matrix theory statistics! RMT as a discipline has two components: the development of random matrix theory per se, and the application of the theory to new physical and mathematical problems. The work of the PI will impact both components. In the theory of integrable systems, two of the problems in particular proposed by the PI, arise directly from technology, viz., laser mode asymptotics, and the effect of perturbations on fiber optical transmission systems. The PI and his collaborators are also writing basic texts on RHPs and RMT aimed at the researchers as well as advanced graduate students entering the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Starting about 8 or 9 years ago, the PI et al have been analyzing the performance of a variety of numerical algorithms when applied to random data. What they found was the following new universality phenomenon: For a wide variety of standard numerical algorithms applied  to random data, the statistical behavior of the normalized stopping times for the algorithms to achieve a given accuracy was universal, independent of the  choice of ensemble for the random initial data. The PI et al first noticed this phenomenon in analyzing a wide variety of standard algorithms to compute the eigenvalues of a random matrix. Then they observed the same phenomenon in solving linear systems of equations with random coefficients, and also in solving genuinely infinite dimensional problems such as the Dirichlet problem in random regions in the plane with random boundary data. They also observed the same universality phenomenon for genuinely stochastic algorithms such as the genetic algorithm to compute the density of states of a random particle system. In view of the above evidence for universality in numerical computation, and in view of a common  model of neuroscientists that the human brain is just a computer with hardware and software, the PI et al then speculated that one should be able to find evidence of universality in some neural computations. And indeed, such universality can be found in a recent set of decision making experiments with live subjects by Bakhtin and Correll: Moreover Bakhtin and Correll constructed a model which explains the universality. Whereas all the preceding work was numerical and experimental, the PI et al have also analyzed various numerical algorithms rigorously and have shown that the statistics for the normalized stopping times is indeed universal: Moreover the PI et al computed the limiting universal histogram for the stopping times explicitly in terms of random matrix theory.  These computations establish universality as a bona fide, new phenomenon in numerical computation.

Recently the PI et al have started investigating universality in cryptographic algorithms. In particular the PI et al have found evidence of universality for RSA and ECC key generation, and also for the so-called Pollard "rho" walk to solve the discrete logarithm problem. This work is in its early stages and is ongoing.

The universality phenomenon described above that came to the fore in numerical computation, is also emerging in  various other fields such as decision making processes and also in medicine: For example, universality phenomena have recently been recognized in epidemiological studies of incubation periods for the spread of flu in a class room as well as in the development of cancer following an incident in a mine. Although the incubation periods for these two situations are very different, weeks in the former case, and years in the latter case, nevertheless the normalized statistics for the incubation periods in both cases is exactly the same ---universality!

.......................................................................................................................

Over the last few years, the PI et al have been considering the asymptotic behavior of a log gas of particles,  in the bulk scaling limit and in the presence of an external potential, as the strength v of the potential and its range s go to infinity. Building on the work of many researchers over the years, the PI et al were able to understand the asymptotic behavior of the gas in all regions of the (v,s) plane, except for the critical  transitional region as v/s increases to 1. Recently the PI et al have been able to analyze the gas in this region so the asymptotic behavior of the gas is now understood for all values of the physical parameters. This finally resolves a problem that has been open for more than 50 years.

...........................................................................................................................

In another direction, the PI et al have resolved a long standing conjecture of Basor  and Tracy  on the asymptotics behavior of Toeplitz determinants with Fisher-Hartwig singularities. Such determinants are very common in mathematics and physics, and occur, in particular, in the analysis of the famous Ising model in two dimensions.

............................................................................................................................

In yet another direction, the PI et al have completed their analysis of the asymptotic behavior of the recurrence coefficients for polynomials orthogonal with respect to a logarithmic weight on the interval [0,1]. En route they resolved an outstanding conjecture of A.Magnus for these coefficients. Logarithmic weights lie at the core of a variety of problems in physics and also in mathematics.

..............................................................................................................................

Finally, the PI et al have written a text on the application of Random Matrix Theory to problems in combinatorics. The application of Random Matrix Theory to problems in combinatorics/random particle systems has emerged as a major theme in modern probability theory.

.....................................................................................................................................
